017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.random.EnhancedRandom;
023
024import java.util.Random;
025
026/**
027 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the YCwCm color space.
028 */
029public class ColorTools {
030        /**
031         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, Y (luma or lightness), Cw
032         * (chromatic warmth), Cm (chromatic mildness), and A (alpha or opacity).
033         * Luma should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for
034         * very light colors (almost only white). The two chroma values range from 0.0 to 1.0, and there's some aesthetic
035         * value in changing just one chroma value. When warm is high and mild is low, the color is more reddish, when both
036         * are low it is more bluish, when mild is high and warm is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are
037         * high it tends to be brown or yellow. When warm and mild are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha
038         * is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
039         * <br>
040         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as luma,
041         * warm, and mild, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original Y, Cw, and Cm
042         * values if the original values were a valid YCwCm color and not an "imaginary color." {@link #fromRGBA(float)}
043         * should always produce a valid YCwCm color.
044         *
045         * @param luma       0f to 1f, luma or Y component of YCwCm, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
046         * @param warm       0f to 1f, "chroma warm" or Cw component of YCwCm, with 1f more red or yellow
047         * @param mild       0f to 1f, "chroma mild" or Cm component of YCwCm, with 1f more green or yellow
048         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
049         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
050         */
051        public static float ycwcm(float luma, float warm, float mild, float alpha) {
052                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (mild * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
053                                | ((int) (warm * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (luma * 255) & 0xFF));
054        }
055
056        /**
057         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
058         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
059         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
060         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
061         */
062        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
063        {
064                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
065                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
066                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
067                return Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 24
068                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
069                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
070                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
071        }
072
073        /**
074         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
075         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
076         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
077         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
078         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
079         */
080        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
081        {
082                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
083                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
084                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
085                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF)
086                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
087                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
088                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
089        }
090
091        /**
092         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
093         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
094         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
095         */
096        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
097                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba >>> 24) * 3 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) >> 3)
098                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 24) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
099                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
100                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
101        }
102
103        /**
104         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
105         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
106         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
107         */
108        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
109                final int rgba = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
110                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba & 0xFF) * 3 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) >> 3)
111                                | (0xFF + (rgba & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
112                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
113                                | (rgba >>> 24 & 0xFE) << 24);
114        }
115
116        /**
117         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
118         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
119         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
120         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
121         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
122         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
123         */
124        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
125                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((int) (255 * (r * 0x3p-3f + g * 0x4p-3f + b * 0x1p-3f)) & 0xFF
126                                                | (int)((r - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00
127                                                | (int)((g - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000
128                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
129        }
130
131        /**
132         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
133         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
134         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
135         */
136        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
137        {
138                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
139                return (decoded & 0xff) + (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 5 >>> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >>> 2);
140        }
141
142        /**
143         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
144         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
145         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
146         */
147        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
148        {
149                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
150                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 3 >> 4) + (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 2);
151        }
152
153        /**
154         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
155         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
156         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
157         */
158        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
159        {
160                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
161                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 3 >> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 2);
162        }
163
164        /**
165         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
166         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
167         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
168         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
169         */
170        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
171        {
172                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
173        }
174
175        /**
176         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
177         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
178         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
179         */
180        public static float red(final float encoded)
181        {
182                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
183                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f + ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0x1.414142p-9f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
184        }
185
186        /**
187         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
188         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
189         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
190         */
191        public static float green(final float encoded)
192        {
193                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
194                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) + ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
195        }
196
197        /**
198         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
199         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
200         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
201         */
202        public static float blue(final float encoded)
203        {
204                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
205                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
206        }
207
208        /**
209         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
210         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
211         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
212         */
213        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
214        {
215                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0.003937008f;
216        }
217
218
219        /**
220         * Gets a color as a YCwCm packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
221         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
222         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
223         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
224         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
225         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
226         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
227         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
228         *
229         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
230         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
231         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
232         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
233         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
234         */
235        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
236                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
237                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
238                } else {
239                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
240                }
241        }
242
243        /**
244         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
245         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
246         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
247         */
248        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
249                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
250                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
251                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
252                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
253                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
254                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
255                float x, y, w;
256                if(g < b) {
257                        x = b;
258                        y = g;
259                }
260                else {
261                        x = g;
262                        y = b;
263                }
264                if(r < x) {
265                        w = r;
266                }
267                else {
268                        w = x;
269                        x = r;
270                }
271                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
272                float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
273                return (x - li) / (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
274        }
275
276        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
277                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
278                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
279                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
280                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
281                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
282                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
283                float x, y, w;
284                if(g < b) {
285                        x = b;
286                        y = g;
287                }
288                else {
289                        x = g;
290                        y = b;
291                }
292                if(r < x) {
293                        w = r;
294                }
295                else {
296                        w = x;
297                        x = r;
298                }
299                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
300                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
301        }
302
303        /**
304         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
305         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
306         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
307         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
308         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
309         */
310        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
311                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
312                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
313                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
314                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
315                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
316                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
317                float x, y, z, w;
318                if(g < b) {
319                        x = b;
320                        y = g;
321                        z = -1f;
322                        w = 2f / 3f;
323                }
324                else {
325                        x = g;
326                        y = b;
327                        z = 0f;
328                        w = -1f / 3f;
329                }
330                if(r < x) {
331                        z = w;
332                        w = r;
333                }
334                else {
335                        w = x;
336                        x = r;
337                }
338                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
339                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
340        }
341
342        /**
343         * The "luma" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
344         * 1.0f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
345         * <ul>
346         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
347         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
348         *     afterwards,</li>
349         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
350         *     afterwards,</li>
351         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
352         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
353         * </ul>
354         * @param encoded a packed float
355         * @return the luma as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
356         */
357        public static float luma(final float encoded)
358        {
359                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
360//        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
361//        return (bits & 0xFF) * 0x3p-11f + (bits >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-9f + (bits >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-11f;
362        }
363
364        /**
365         * The "chroma warm" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma mild describes the
366         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
367         * <ul>
368         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
369         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
370         *     afterwards,</li>
371         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
372         *     afterwards,</li>
373         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
374         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
375         * </ul>
376         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
377         * @return the chroma warm as a float from 0f to 1f
378         */
379        public static float chromaWarm(final float encoded)
380        {
381                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
382        }
383
384        /**
385         * The "chroma mild" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma warm describes the
386         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f .
387         * YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
388         * <ul>
389         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
390         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
391         *     afterwards,</li>
392         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
393         *     afterwards,</li>
394         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
395         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
396         * </ul>
397         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
398         * @return the chroma mild as a float from 0f to 1f
399         */
400        public static float chromaMild(final float encoded)
401        {
402                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
403        }
404
405        /**
406         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
407         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not YCwCm! Takes
408         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
409         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
410         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
411         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
412         * <br>
413         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
414         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
415         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
416         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
417         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
418         *
419         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
420         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
421         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
422         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
423         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
424         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
425         */
426        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
427                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
428                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
429                if (light + (e & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f <= 0.001f)
430                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
431                final int lu = (e & 0xff);
432                final int cw = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff);
433                final int cm = (((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
434                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light + (cw * 0.625f) - cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
435                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light - (cw * 0.375f) + cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
436                final float b = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light - (cw * 0.375f) - cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
437                float x, y, z, w;
438                if(g < b) {
439                        x = b;
440                        y = g;
441                        z = -1f;
442                        w = 2f / 3f;
443                }
444                else {
445                        x = g;
446                        y = b;
447                        z = 0f;
448                        w = -1f / 3f;
449                }
450                if(r < x) {
451                        z = w;
452                        w = r;
453                }
454                else {
455                        w = x;
456                        x = r;
457                }
458                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
459                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
460                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
461                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
462                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
463        }
464
465        /**
466         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
467         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
468         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
469         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
470         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
471         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
472         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
473         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
474         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
475         */
476        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
477                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
478                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma + (0xFF - luma) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
479        }
480
481        /**
482         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
483         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
484         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
485         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
486         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
487         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
488         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
489         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
490         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
491         */
492        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
493                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
494                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
495        }
496
497        /**
498         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (yellow to red) by change. While change
499         * should be between 0f (returnstart as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
500         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
501         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
502         * a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
503         * as-is.
504         * @see #cool(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
505         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
506         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
507         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
508         */
509        public static float warm(final float start, final float change) {
510                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
511                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
516         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
517         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
518         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
519         * a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
520         * as-is.
521         * @see #warm(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
522         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
523         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
524         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
525         */
526        public static float cool(final float start, final float change) {
527                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
528                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
529        }
530
531        /**
532         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a milder color (between green and yellow) by change. While
533         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully mild), start should be a packed color, as
534         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
535         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
536         * towards a milder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
537         * start as-is.
538         * @see #strengthen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more bold
539         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
540         * @param change how much to change start to a milder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a milder result
541         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a milder color
542         */
543        public static float weaken(final float start, final float change) {
544                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
545                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
546        }
547
548        /**
549         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a bolder color (between blue and red) by change. While
550         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as
551         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
552         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
553         * towards a bolder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
554         * start as-is.
555         * @see #weaken(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more mild
556         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
557         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a bolder result
558         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a bolder color
559         */
560        public static float strengthen(final float start, final float change) {
561                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
562                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
563        }
564
565        /**
566         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
567         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
568         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
569         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
570         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
571         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
572         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
573         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
574         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
575         */
576        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
577                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
578                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
579        }
580
581        /**
582         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
583         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
584         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
585         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
586         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
587         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
588         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
589         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
590         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
591         */
592        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
593                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
594                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
595        }
596
597        /**
598         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
599         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
600         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes Cw and Cm; it leaves Y and alpha alone, unlike
601         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes Y.
602         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
603         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
604         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
605         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
606         */
607        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
608                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
609                return ycwcm((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
610                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
611                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
612                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
613        }
614
615        /**
616         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
617         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
618         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only Cw and Cm, but higher values for
619         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
620         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change Y somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
621         * then Y won't change; alpha never changes.
622         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
623         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
624         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
625         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
626         */
627        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
628                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
629                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
630                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
631                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
632                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
633        }
634
635        /**
636         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
637         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with roughly inverted luma but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw
638         * and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or
639         * other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for luma values between 0.5 and 0.55. That
640         * allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
641         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the luma unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
642         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
643         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
644         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
645         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
646         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
647         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
648         * @return a different packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
649         */
650        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
651        {
652                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
653                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
654                                luma = (bits & 0xff),
655                                warm = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
656                                mild = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
657                                cLuma = (contrastBits & 0xff),
658                                cWarm = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
659                                cMild = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
660                if((warm - cWarm) * (warm - cWarm) + (mild - cMild) * (mild - cMild) >= 0x10000)
661                        return mainColor;
662                return ycwcm(cLuma < 128 ? luma * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - luma * (0.45f / 255f), warm / 255f, mild / 255f, 0x1.010102p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
663        }
664
665        /**
666         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
667         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with Y that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s Y,
668         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
669         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
670         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
671         * <br>
672         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
673         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
674         * averages the original Y of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
675         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
676         * @param contrastingColor a packed YCwCm float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the Y of this
677         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
678         */
679        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
680        {
681                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
682                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
683        }
684
685        /**
686         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's Y and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
687         * with the original Y. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
688         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
689         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color
690         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, with its Y channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
691         */
692        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
693                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
694                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
695        }
696
697        /**
698         * Makes the additive YCwCm color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
699         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
700         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
701         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
702         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
703         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
704         * @return a YCwCm float color between gray and {@code color}
705         */
706        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
707                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
708                                ys = 0x7F, cws = 0x7F, cms = 0x7F,
709                                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
710                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + fraction * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
711                                | (((int) (cws + fraction * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
712                                | (((int) (cms + fraction * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
713                                | (ae << 24));
714        }
715        /**
716         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
717         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
718         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
719         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
720         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the Y, Cw, and Cm of the
721         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
722         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers Cw and Cm extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while Y goes from 0 to
723         * 1, but only internally for measuring distance).
724         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
725         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
726         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
727         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
728         */
729        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
730                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
731                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
732                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
733                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
734                final float limit = variance * variance;
735                float dist = limit + 1f, a = 0, b = 0, c = 0;
736                while (dist > limit){
737                        a = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
738                        b = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
739                        c = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
740                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
741                        dist = a * a + b * b + c * c;
742                }
743                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cm + c, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
744                                | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cw + b, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(Math.min(Math.max(y + a, 0), 1) * 255f));
745        }
746
747        /**
748         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as YCwCm, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
749         * @param packed a packed float color as YCwCm
750         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
751         */
752        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
753        {
754                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
755                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
756                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 2);
757                final int r = y + (cw * 5 / 8) - cm;
758                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
759                final int g = y - (cw * 3 / 8) + cm;
760                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
761                final int b = y - (cw * 3 / 8) - cm;
762                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
763        }
764        /**
765         * Returns true if the given YCwCm values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
766         * @param y luma channel, as a float from 0 to 1
767         * @param cw chromatic warmth channel, as a float from 0 to 1
768         * @param cm chromatic mildness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
769         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
770         */
771        public static boolean inGamut(float y, float cw, float cm)
772        {
773                final int yi = (int)(y * 255.999f), cwi = (int) ((cw - 0.5f) * 511.999f), cmi = (int) ((cm - 0.5f) * 255.999f);
774                final int r = yi + (cwi * 5 / 8) - cmi;
775                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
776                final int g = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) + cmi;
777                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
778                final int b = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) - cmi;
779                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
780        }
781
782        /**
783         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
784         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
785         * @param packed a packed float color in YCwCm format; often this color is not in-gamut
786         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
787         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
788         */
789        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
790                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
791                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
792                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
793                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 255f;
794                float cw2 = cw, cm2 = cm;
795                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
796                        final float r = y + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
797                        final float g = y - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
798                        final float b = y - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
799                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
800                                break;
801                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
802                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
803                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
804                }
805                return ycwcm(y, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
806        }
807
808        /**
809         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
810         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
811         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
812         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
813         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
814         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
815         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
816         */
817        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm) {
818                return limitToGamut(y, cw, cm, 1f);
819        }
820
821        /**
822         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
823         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
824         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
825         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
826         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
827         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
828         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
829         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
830         */
831        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm, float a)
832        {
833                float y2 = Math.min(Math.max(y, 0f), 1f);
834                float cw2 = cw = Math.min(Math.max((cw - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
835                float cm2 = cm = Math.min(Math.max((cm - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
836                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
837                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
838                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
839                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
840                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
841                                break;
842                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
843                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
844                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
845                }
846                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f));
847        }
848
849        /**
850         * Given a packed float YCwCm color, this edits its luma (Y), chromatic warmth (Cw), chromatic mildness (Cm), and
851         * alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float
852         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
853         * you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert
854         * it back to RGBA.
855         * @param encoded a packed float YCwCm color
856         * @param addY how much to add to the luma channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
857         * @param addCw how much to add to the chromatic warmth channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
858         * @param addCm how much to add to the chromatic mildness channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
859         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
860         * @return a packed float YCwCm color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
861         */
862        public static float editYCwCm(float encoded, float addY, float addCw, float addCm, float addAlpha) {
863                return editYCwCm(encoded, addY, addCw, addCm, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
864        }
865        /**
866         * Given a packed float YCwCm color, this edits its luma (Y), chromatic warmth (Cw), chromatic mildness (Cm), and
867         * alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the
868         * corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means the luma value is multiplied by {@code mulY}, then has
869         * {@code addY} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for luma (0 to 1). This returns a different float
870         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
871         * you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this
872         * manipulates chromatic warmth and mildness in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like
873         * {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like
874         * {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut,
875         * so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
876         * @param encoded a packed float YCwCm color
877         * @param addY how much to add to the luma channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
878         * @param addCw how much to add to the chromatic warmth channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
879         * @param addCm how much to add to the chromatic mildness channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
880         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
881         * @param mulY how much to multiply the luma channel by; should be non-negative
882         * @param mulCw how much to multiply the chromatic warmth channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
883         * @param mulCm how much to multiply the chromatic mildness channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
884         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
885         * @return a packed float YCwCm color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
886         */
887        public static float editYCwCm(float encoded, float addY, float addCw, float addCm, float addAlpha,
888                                                                  float mulY, float mulCw, float mulCm, float mulAlpha) {
889                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
890                float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
891                float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
892                float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
893                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
894
895                float y2 = Math.min(Math.max(y * mulY + addY, 0f), 1f);
896                float cw2 = cw = Math.min(Math.max(cw * mulCw + addCw, -1f), 1f);
897                float cm2 = cm = Math.min(Math.max(cm * mulCm + addCm, -1f), 1f);
898                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
899                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
900                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
901                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
902                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
903                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
904                                break;
905                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
906                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
907                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
908                }
909                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
910        }
911
912        /**
913         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
914         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.LaserRandom})
915         * @return a random opaque packed float color that is always in-gamut
916         */
917        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
918                final float yr = +0.375f, wr = +0.5f, mr = +0.0f;
919                final float yg = +0.500f, wg = +0.0f, mg = +0.5f;
920                final float yb = +0.125f, wb = -0.5f, mb = -0.5f;
921                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
922                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
923                                | ((int) ((mr * r + mg * g + mb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
924                                | ((int) ((wr * r + wg * g + wb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
925                                | ((int) ((yr * r + yg * g + yb * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
926        }
927
928        /**
929         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
930         * This is named differently from {@link #randomColor(Random)} to avoid confusion when a class both extends Random
931         * and EnhancedRandom.
932         * @param random any subclass of juniper's EnhancedRandom, such as a
933         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.DistinctRandom} or
934         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.FourWheelRandom}
935         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
936         */
937        public static float randomizedColor(EnhancedRandom random) {
938                final float yr = +0.375f, wr = +0.5f, mr = +0.0f;
939                final float yg = +0.500f, wg = +0.0f, mg = +0.5f;
940                final float yb = +0.125f, wb = -0.5f, mb = -0.5f;
941                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
942                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
943                                | ((int) ((mr * r + mg * g + mb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
944                                | ((int) ((wr * r + wg * g + wb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
945                                | ((int) ((yr * r + yg * g + yb * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
946        }
947}
